questions.text: What planet is known as the Red Planet?
questions.explanation: Mars appears red due to iron oxide (rust) on its surface.

questions.text: What is the chemical symbol for gold?
questions.explanation: Au comes from the Latin word 'aurum' meaning gold.

questions.text: What is the speed of light in vacuum?
questions.explanation: The speed of light is approximately 300,000 km/s or 299,792,458 m/s.

questions.text: What is DNA short for?
questions.explanation: DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid, which carries genetic information.

questions.text: At what temperature does water boil at sea level?
questions.explanation: Water boils at 100°C (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure.

questions.text: What is the most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

questions.text: Which organ in the human body is responsible for producing insulin?
questions.explanation: The pancreas produces insulin to regulate blood sugar levels.

questions.text: What is the hardest natural substance on Earth?
questions.explanation: Diamond scores 10 on the Mohs hardness scale.

questions.text: Who developed the theory of evolution by natural selection?
questions.explanation: Charles Darwin published 'On the Origin of Species' in 1859.

questions.text: What is the primary source of energy for Earth’s climate system?
questions.explanation: The Sun provides nearly all the energy that drives weather and climate.

questions.text: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria generate most of the cell’s ATP through cellular respiration.

questions.text: Which planet has the most moons?
questions.explanation: As of 2025, Saturn has 145 confirmed moons, surpassing Jupiter.

questions.text: What is the pH of pure water?
questions.explanation: Pure water is neutral with a pH of 7.

questions.text: Who proposed the theory of relativity?
questions.explanation: Albert Einstein published the special and general theories of relativity.

questions.text: What is the largest organ in the human body?
questions.explanation: The skin is the body’s largest organ by surface area and weight.

questions.text: Which blood type is known as the universal donor?
questions.explanation: O-negative blood can be given to anyone regardless of their blood type.

questions.text: What gas do plants absorb from the atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Plants take in CO₂ during photosynthesis to produce glucose and oxygen.

questions.text: What is the atomic number of carbon?
questions.explanation: Carbon has 6 protons, hence atomic number 6.

questions.text: Which scientist discovered penicillin?
questions.explanation: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928.

questions.text: What is the unit of electrical resistance?
questions.explanation: Resistance is measured in ohms (Ω).

questions.text: Which layer of the Earth is made mostly of iron and nickel?
questions.explanation: The inner core is solid and composed primarily of iron and nickel.

questions.text: What is the chemical formula for table salt?
questions.explanation: Table salt is sodium chloride (NaCl).

questions.text: What is the only letter not appearing on the periodic table?
questions.explanation: The letter 'J' does not appear in any element symbol.

questions.text: Which vitamin is produced when skin is exposed to sunlight?
questions.explanation: UVB rays convert 7-dehydrocholesterol in the skin to vitamin D₃.

questions.text: What is the name of our galaxy?
questions.explanation: We live in the Milky Way, a barred spiral galaxy.

questions.text: What force keeps planets in orbit around the Sun?
questions.explanation: Gravity is the attractive force between masses.

questions.text: Which element has the highest electronegativity?
questions.explanation: Fluorine has the highest electronegativity value of 3.98.

questions.text: What is the main gas responsible for the greenhouse effect?
questions.explanation: CO₂ traps heat in the atmosphere, contributing most to the greenhouse effect.

questions.text: What is the smallest unit of life?
questions.explanation: The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.

questions.text: Which planet is closest to the Sun?
questions.explanation: Mercury is the innermost planet in the Solar System.

questions.text: What is the boiling point of water in Fahrenheit?
questions.explanation: Water boils at 212°F at sea level (100°C).

questions.text: Which scientist discovered radioactivity?
questions.explanation: Henri Becquerel discovered radioactivity in 1896; Marie Curie coined the term.

questions.text: What is the most common blood type worldwide?
questions.explanation: O-positive is the most common blood type globally.

questions.text: What is the hardest bone in the human body?
questions.explanation: The mandible (lower jaw) is the strongest and hardest bone.

questions.text: Which gas makes up about 21% of Earth’s atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Oxygen constitutes approximately 21% of the atmosphere.

questions.text: What is the center of an atom called?
questions.explanation: The nucleus contains protons and neutrons.

questions.text: Which planet is known as the 'Jewel of the Solar System'?
questions.explanation: Saturn’s spectacular ring system earned it this nickname.

questions.text: What is the chemical symbol for iron?
questions.explanation: Fe comes from the Latin 'ferrum'.

questions.text: Which part of the brain controls balance and coordination?
questions.explanation: The cerebellum is responsible for motor control and coordination.

questions.text: What is the freezing point of water in Celsius?
questions.explanation: Water freezes at 0°C (32°F) at standard pressure.

questions.text: In which year did World War II end?
questions.explanation: World War II ended in 1945 with the surrender of Japan in September.

questions.text: Who was the first President of the United States?
questions.explanation: George Washington served as the first President from 1789 to 1797.

questions.text: When did the French Revolution begin?
questions.explanation: The French Revolution began in 1789 with the storming of the Bastille.

questions.text: Who was the last pharaoh of Ancient Egypt?
questions.explanation: Cleopatra VII ruled until 30 BCE when Egypt became a Roman province.

questions.text: In which year did the Berlin Wall fall?
questions.explanation: The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, symbolizing the end of the Cold War.

questions.text: Who led India to independence from British rule?
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi led the non-violent independence movement.

questions.text: Who was the first Emperor of Rome?
questions.explanation: Augustus (formerly Octavian) became the first Roman emperor in 27 BCE.

questions.text: In which year did Christopher Columbus reach the Americas?
questions.explanation: Columbus landed on an island in the Bahamas on October 12, 1492.

questions.text: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
questions.explanation: Leonardo da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa between 1503 and 1506.

questions.text: Which event started World War I?
questions.explanation: The assassination in Sarajevo on June 28, 1914, triggered the war.

questions.text: Who was the longest-reigning British monarch before Queen Elizabeth II?
questions.explanation: Queen Victoria reigned for 63 years and 216 days (1837–1901).

questions.text: In which year did the Titanic sink?
questions.explanation: The Titanic sank on April 15, 1912, after hitting an iceberg.

questions.text: Who wrote the Declaration of Independence?
questions.explanation: Thomas Jefferson was the primary author in 1776.

questions.text: Which empire was ruled by Genghis Khan?
questions.explanation: Genghis Khan founded the largest contiguous empire in history.

questions.text: Who was the first man to walk on the Moon?
questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong stepped onto the Moon on July 20, 1969.

questions.text: Which wall was built by the Romans in Britain?
questions.explanation: Emperor Hadrian ordered its construction in 122 CE to mark the northern frontier.

questions.text: Who was known as the 'Maid of Orléans'?
questions.explanation: Joan of Arc led French forces during the Hundred Years’ War.

questions.text: In which year did India gain independence?
questions.explanation: India became independent from Britain on August 15, 1947.

questions.text: Who was the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher served from 1979 to 1990.

questions.text: Which city was the ancient capital of the Inca Empire?
questions.explanation: Cuzco (or Cusco) was the political and religious center of the Inca Empire.

questions.text: Who discovered the law of universal gravitation after an apple fell on his head (legend)?
questions.explanation: Isaac Newton formulated the law of universal gravitation in 1687.

questions.text: Which war was fought between the years 1939–1945?
questions.explanation: World War II was the deadliest conflict in human history.

questions.text: Who was the primary author of the Communist Manifesto?
questions.explanation: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels published it in 1848.

questions.text: Which ancient wonder was located in Alexandria?
questions.explanation: The Pharos (Lighthouse) of Alexandria was one of the Seven Wonders.

questions.text: Who led the Salt March in 1930?
questions.explanation: Gandhi’s 240-mile march protested the British salt tax.

questions.text: Which country was unified by Otto von Bismarck in 1871?
questions.explanation: Bismarck unified the German states into the German Empire.

questions.text: What is the capital of France?
questions.explanation: Paris is the capital and most populous city of France.

questions.text: Which is the largest ocean on Earth?
questions.explanation: The Pacific Ocean covers about 46% of Earth's water surface.

questions.text: What is the tallest mountain in the world?
questions.explanation: Mount Everest stands at 8,848.86 meters (29,031.7 feet) above sea level.

questions.text: Which country has the longest coastline in the world?
questions.explanation: Canada’s coastline stretches over 202,080 km due to its many islands.

questions.text: What is the capital of Brazil?
questions.explanation: Brasília was purpose-built as the capital and inaugurated in 1960.

questions.text: Which desert is the largest in the world?
questions.explanation: The Antarctic Desert (polar desert) is larger than the Sahara.

questions.text: What is the smallest country in the world by land area?
questions.explanation: Vatican City covers just 44 hectares (0.17 sq mi).

questions.text: Which river is the longest in the world?
questions.explanation: The Nile River is approximately 6,650 km long.

questions.text: What is the capital of Japan?
questions.explanation: Tokyo is the world’s most populous metropolitan area.

questions.text: Which country is both in Europe and Asia?
questions.explanation: Turkey straddles the Bosphorus Strait, with territory on both continents.

questions.text: What is the largest country by land area?
questions.explanation: Russia covers over 17 million square kilometers.

questions.text: Which sea has no coastline?
questions.explanation: The Sargasso Sea is defined by ocean currents, not land borders.

questions.text: What is the capital of Australia?
questions.explanation: Canberra was chosen as a compromise between Sydney and Melbourne.

questions.text: Which continent is the Sahara Desert located in?
questions.explanation: The Sahara is the largest hot desert and covers much of North Africa.

questions.text: Which country has the most time zones?
questions.explanation: France has 12 time zones due to its overseas territories.

questions.text: What is the deepest point in the ocean?
questions.explanation: The Challenger Deep in the Mariana Trench is 10,984 meters deep.

questions.text: Which African country is known as the 'Rainbow Nation'?
questions.explanation: The term was coined by Desmond Tutu after apartheid ended.

questions.text: Which country is home to the Amazon Rainforest (largest part)?
questions.explanation: About 60% of the Amazon lies within Brazil.

questions.text: What is the only continent without an active volcano?
questions.explanation: Australia is the only continent with no currently active volcanoes.

questions.text: Which European country has the most lakes?
questions.explanation: Finland has approximately 188,000 lakes and is called 'Land of a Thousand Lakes'.

questions.text: Which city is located on two continents?
questions.explanation: Istanbul straddles Europe and Asia across the Bosphorus.

questions.text: What is the capital of Egypt?
questions.explanation: Cairo is one of the largest cities in Africa and the Arab world.

questions.text: Which country has the most islands in the world?
questions.explanation: Sweden has over 267,000 islands, mostly small and uninhabited.

questions.text: Which mountain range separates Europe from Asia?
questions.explanation: The Ural Mountains form the conventional boundary between the two continents.

questions.text: Which is the hottest continent on Earth?
questions.explanation: Africa contains the hottest consistently recorded places (e.g., Sahara).

questions.text: What is the capital of Canada?
questions.explanation: Ottawa is the political capital of Canada.

questions.text: Who is credited with inventing the World Wide Web?
questions.explanation: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 at CERN.

questions.text: What does CPU stand for?
questions.explanation: CPU stands for Central Processing Unit, the brain of a computer.

questions.text: In what year was the first iPhone released?
questions.explanation: Apple released the first iPhone on June 29, 2007.

questions.text: What does 'Wi-Fi' stand for?
questions.explanation: 'Wi-Fi' is a trademark name and was never meant to be an acronym.

questions.text: Which company created the Android operating system?
questions.explanation: Google acquired Android Inc. in 2005 and released it in 2008.

questions.text: What does USB stand for?
questions.explanation: USB is a standard for connecting devices and transferring data.

questions.text: What does 'HTTP' stand for?
questions.explanation: HTTP is the foundation of data communication on the World Wide Web.

questions.text: Who founded Microsoft?
questions.explanation: Bill Gates and Paul Allen founded Microsoft on April 4, 1975.

questions.text: What does 'GPU' stand for?
questions.explanation: GPU handles rendering images, videos, and animations.

questions.text: Which programming language was created by Guido van Rossum?
questions.explanation: Python was released in 1991 and is known for its readability.

questions.text: What does 'AI' stand for?
questions.explanation: Artificial Intelligence refers to machines simulating human intelligence.

questions.text: In what year was the first email sent?
questions.explanation: Ray Tomlinson sent the first networked email in 1971.

questions.text: What does 'RAM' stand for?
questions.explanation: RAM is volatile memory used for temporary data storage.

questions.text: Which company created the first commercially successful personal computer (Apple II)?
questions.explanation: The Apple II, released in 1977, was a huge success.

questions.text: What does 'URL' stand for?
questions.explanation: URL is the address used to locate resources on the web.

questions.text: Who is known as the father of the computer?
questions.explanation: Charles Babbage designed the Analytical Engine in the 1830s.

questions.text: What does 'VPN' stand for?
questions.explanation: VPNs create secure connections over the internet.

questions.text: Which was the first search engine on the internet?
questions.explanation: Archie, launched in 1990, was the first search engine.

questions.text: What does 'OLED' stand for in display technology?
questions.explanation: OLED displays produce light when electricity is applied.

questions.text: Who co-founded Apple with Steve Jobs?
questions.explanation: Steve Wozniak designed the Apple I and Apple II.

questions.text: What does 'SSD' stand for?
questions.explanation: SSDs use flash memory and are faster than traditional HDDs.

questions.text: Which company developed the Java programming language?
questions.explanation: Java was released by Sun Microsystems in 1995.

questions.text: What does 'HTML' stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML is the standard markup language for creating web pages.

questions.text: Which was the first company to reach a $1 trillion market cap?
questions.explanation: Apple hit $1 trillion on August 2, 2018.

questions.text: What does 'Bluetooth' refer to?
questions.explanation: Named after King Harald 'Bluetooth' Gormsson who united tribes.

questions.text: Which file format is commonly used for images on the web?
questions.explanation: PNG supports transparency and lossless compression.

questions.text: Who invented the computer mouse?
questions.explanation: Douglas Engelbart demonstrated the mouse in 1968.

questions.text: What does 'PDF' stand for?
questions.explanation: PDF preserves document formatting across devices.

questions.text: Which language is primarily used for Android app development?
questions.explanation: Kotlin is now the preferred language for Android development.

questions.text: What does 'IP' stand for in IP address?
questions.explanation: IP addresses identify devices on a network.

questions.text: Which company owns YouTube?
questions.explanation: Google acquired YouTube in 2006 for $1.65 billion.

questions.text: What does 'CAD' stand for in design software?
questions.explanation: CAD software is used in engineering and architecture.

questions.text: Which was the first video game console?
questions.explanation: The Magnavox Odyssey was released in 1972.

questions.text: What does 'QR' in QR code stand for?
questions.explanation: QR codes were invented in 1994 by Denso Wave in Japan.

questions.text: Which file system is used by Windows by default?
questions.explanation: NTFS is the default file system for modern Windows versions.

questions.text: Who created the Linux kernel?
questions.explanation: Linus Torvalds released the first Linux kernel in 1991.

questions.text: What does 'GIF' stand for?
questions.explanation: GIF supports animation and 256 colors.

questions.text: Which company makes the PlayStation?
questions.explanation: Sony released the first PlayStation in 1994.

questions.text: What does 'WWW' stand for?
questions.explanation: The World Wide Web is a system of interlinked hypertext documents.

questions.text: Which protocol is used to send emails?
questions.explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) sends outgoing emails.

questions.text: What does 'ROM' stand for in computing?
questions.explanation: ROM retains data even when the computer is turned off.

questions.text: Which company created the Swift programming language?
questions.explanation: Swift was introduced by Apple in 2014 for iOS and macOS development.

questions.text: What is the name of SpaceX’s reusable rocket?
questions.explanation: Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy are SpaceX’s flagship rockets.

questions.text: What does 'BIOS' stand for?
questions.explanation: BIOS initializes hardware during booting.

questions.text: Which cryptocurrency was the first decentralized one?
questions.explanation: Bitcoin was created by Satoshi Nakamoto in 2009.

questions.text: What does 'DNS' stand for?
questions.explanation: DNS translates domain names into IP addresses.

questions.text: How many players are there on a standard basketball team on the court at once?
questions.explanation: 5 players per team (total 10) are on the court at the same time.

questions.text: In which sport can you score a 'hole-in-one'?
questions.explanation: A hole-in-one is when a golfer gets the ball in the hole with one stroke from the tee.

questions.text: How long is a football (soccer) match?
questions.explanation: A standard match consists of two 45-minute halves (90 minutes total).

questions.text: Which country has won the most FIFA World Cups (men’s)?
questions.explanation: Brazil has won the World Cup 5 times (1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, 2002).

questions.text: How many rings are there on the Olympic symbol?
questions.explanation: The five interlocking rings represent the union of the five inhabited continents.

questions.text: In tennis, what is the score of zero called?
questions.explanation: The term 'love' for zero comes from the French 'l’œuf' (egg), resembling a zero.

questions.text: Which sport is played at Wimbledon?
questions.explanation: Wimbledon hosts the oldest and most prestigious tennis tournament.

questions.text: How high is a basketball hoop from the ground?
questions.explanation: The standard height is 10 feet (3.05 meters).

questions.text: Which country invented baseball?
questions.explanation: Baseball evolved in the United States in the 19th century.

questions.text: In which sport can you perform a 'slam dunk'?
questions.explanation: A slam dunk is when a player jumps and scores by putting the ball directly through the hoop.

questions.text: How many players are on a cricket team on the field?
questions.explanation: 11 players per side in professional cricket.

questions.text: Which athlete has won the most Olympic gold medals?
questions.explanation: Michael Phelps has 23 Olympic gold medals (swimming).

questions.text: In which sport is the term 'ace' used?
questions.explanation: An ace is a serve that lands in the opponent’s court untouched.

questions.text: How long is an Olympic swimming pool?
questions.explanation: Olympic pools are 50 meters long (long course).

questions.text: Which country won the first ever FIFA World Cup in 1930?
questions.explanation: Uruguay defeated Argentina 4–2 in the final.

questions.text: How many points is a touchdown worth in American football?
questions.explanation: A touchdown is worth 6 points (+1 or 2 for conversion).

questions.text: Which Grand Slam tennis tournament is played on clay courts?
questions.explanation: The French Open (Roland Garros) is the only Grand Slam on clay.

questions.text: What is the maximum score possible with 3 darts in one turn?
questions.explanation: Three triple-20s = 3 × 60 = 180.

questions.text: Which sport uses the term 'love' for a score of zero?
questions.explanation: All racket sports derived scoring from tennis.

questions.text: In which year were the first modern Olympic Games held?
questions.explanation: The first modern Olympics were held in Athens, Greece in 1896.

questions.text: How many holes are there in a full round of golf?
questions.explanation: A standard round of golf is 18 holes.

questions.text: Which country has hosted the most Summer Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: USA has hosted 5 Summer Olympics (1904, 1932, 1984, 1996, 2028).

questions.text: What color belt is the highest rank in judo?
questions.explanation: In judo, the highest ranks (6th dan and above) wear red-and-white belts.

questions.text: Which sport features the 'Stanley Cup'?
questions.explanation: The Stanley Cup is awarded to the NHL playoff champion.

questions.text: How many players are on a volleyball team on the court?
questions.explanation: 6 players per team in standard indoor volleyball.

questions.text: Who is known as 'The Greatest' in boxing?
questions.explanation: Muhammad Ali famously called himself 'The Greatest'.

questions.text: In which sport can you win the 'Davis Cup'?
questions.explanation: The Davis Cup is the premier international team event in men’s tennis.

questions.text: How many minutes are played in an NBA basketball game?
questions.explanation: Four 12-minute quarters = 48 minutes total.

questions.text: Which country dominates Olympic table tennis, winning most gold medals?
questions.explanation: China has won over 60% of all Olympic table tennis gold medals.

questions.text: What is the national sport of Japan?
questions.explanation: Sumo is considered Japan’s de facto national sport.

questions.text: How many gold medals did Usain Bolt win in his Olympic career?
questions.explanation: Bolt won 8 Olympic golds (100m, 200m, 4x100m in 2008, 2012, 2016; one later stripped).

questions.text: In rugby union, how many points is a try worth?
questions.explanation: A try is worth 5 points (plus possible conversion).

questions.text: Which city hosted the 2016 Summer Olympics?
questions.explanation: Rio 2016 was the first Olympics held in South America.

questions.text: What is the only sport to be played on the moon?
questions.explanation: Alan Shepard hit a golf ball on the moon during Apollo 14 in 1971.

questions.text: Which country has won the most Rugby World Cups?
questions.explanation: South Africa has won 4 Rugby World Cups (1995, 2007, 2019, 2023).

questions.text: In which sport is the term 'bullseye' used?
questions.explanation: Bullseye is the center of the target in all three sports.

questions.text: Who has scored the most goals in FIFA World Cup history (men’s)?
questions.explanation: Miroslav Klose (Germany) scored 16 goals across four tournaments.

questions.text: How many dimples does an average golf ball have?
questions.explanation: Most golf balls have around 336 dimples (varies by model).

questions.text: Which sport has 9 innings per team?
questions.explanation: A standard baseball game has 9 innings per team.

questions.text: What is the fastest recorded serve in men’s tennis?
questions.explanation: Sam Groth hit a 263.4 km/h serve in 2012.

questions.text: Which country is known as the 'Home of Cricket'?
questions.explanation: Lord’s Cricket Ground in London is called the 'Home of Cricket'.

questions.text: How many players are on an ice hockey team on the ice?
questions.explanation: 6 players per team (5 skaters + 1 goalie).

questions.text: Which female gymnast has won the most Olympic medals?
questions.explanation: Larisa Latynina (USSR) won 18 Olympic medals (9 gold).

questions.text: What is the length of a marathon?
questions.explanation: The official marathon distance is 42.195 kilometers (26 miles 385 yards).

questions.text: Which country has won the most Olympic medals in history?
questions.explanation: The USA has over 2,800 total Olympic medals.

questions.text: In which sport is the 'America’s Cup' contested?
questions.explanation: The America’s Cup is the oldest international trophy in sport (sailing).

questions.text: How many squares are there on a standard chessboard?
questions.explanation: An 8×8 board has 64 squares.

questions.text: Which athlete is known as the 'Fastest Man on Earth'?
questions.explanation: Usain Bolt holds world records in 100m and 200m.

questions.text: Which sport uses a shuttlecock?
questions.explanation: Badminton is played with a shuttlecock (also called a birdie).

questions.text: How many World Cup titles has Lionel Messi won?
questions.explanation: Messi won the 2022 FIFA World Cup with Argentina.

questions.text: In which sport can you hit a 'six'?
questions.explanation: Hitting the ball over the boundary on the full scores 6 runs.

questions.text: Which country has won the most Cricket World Cups (men’s ODI)?
questions.explanation: Australia has won 6 ODI World Cups (1987, 1999, 2003, 2007, 2015, 2023).

questions.text: What is the diameter of a basketball hoop in inches?
questions.explanation: The official rim diameter is 18 inches.

questions.text: Which sport has a playing field called a 'diamond'?
questions.explanation: The infield in baseball is called the diamond.

questions.text: Who won the Ballon d’Or a record 8 times?
questions.explanation: Lionel Messi has won the Ballon d’Or 8 times (2009–2023).

questions.text: In which sport is the 'Heisman Trophy' awarded?
questions.explanation: Given annually to the most outstanding college football player in the USA.

questions.text: How many players from each team are on the field in Australian Rules Football?
questions.explanation: 18 players per team on the oval-shaped field.

questions.text: Which country won the 2020 UEFA European Championship?
questions.explanation: Italy defeated England on penalties in the final at Wembley.

questions.text: What is the only Grand Slam tournament played on grass courts?
questions.explanation: Wimbledon is the only major still played on natural grass.

questions.text: Which NBA player is known as 'King James'?
questions.explanation: LeBron James is widely known as 'King James'.

questions.text: Who is the final Prophet in Islam?
questions.explanation: Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is the Seal of the Prophets (Khatam an-Nabiyyin).

questions.text: How many pillars (arkan) of Islam are there?
questions.explanation: The five pillars are: Shahada, Salah, Zakat, Sawm, and Hajj.

questions.text: What is the first pillar of Islam?
questions.explanation: Shahada: 'There is no god but Allah, and Muhammad is His messenger.'

questions.text: In which cave did Prophet Muhammad (SAW) receive the first revelation?
questions.explanation: The first verses of the Qur’an were revealed in Cave Hira in 610 CE.

questions.text: How many years did the revelation of the Qur’an take?
questions.explanation: 13 years in Makkah + 10 years in Madinah = 23 years total.

questions.text: What is the name of the angel who brought revelation to the Prophet (SAW)?
questions.explanation: Angel Jibreel (Gabriel) delivered the Qur’an to Prophet Muhammad (SAW).

questions.text: How many chapters (surahs) are there in the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: The Qur’an consists of 114 surahs of varying lengths.

questions.text: Which city is known as the 'City of the Prophet'?
questions.explanation: The Prophet (SAW) migrated to Madinah (formerly Yathrib).

questions.text: What is the meaning of 'Islam'?
questions.explanation: Islam means voluntary submission to Allah, which brings peace.

questions.text: Which battle is known as the 'Battle of the Trench' (Ghazwa-e-Khandaq)?
questions.explanation: In 5 AH (627 CE), Muslims dug a trench around Madinah for defense.

questions.text: Which surah is known as the 'Heart of the Qur’an'?
questions.explanation: The Prophet (SAW) called Surah Yaseen the heart of the Qur’an.

questions.text: How many daily obligatory (fard) prayers are there?
questions.explanation: Fajr, Zuhr, Asr, Maghrib, and Isha.

questions.text: What is the night journey of the Prophet (SAW) called?
questions.explanation: Isra (night journey to Jerusalem) and Mi'raj (ascension to heavens).

questions.text: Which prophet is known as 'Friend of Allah' (Khaleelullah)?
questions.explanation: Allah called Prophet Ibrahim (AS) His Khaleel in the Qur’an.

questions.text: What is the longest surah in the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: Surah Al-Baqarah has 286 verses.

questions.text: Which companion was given the title 'The Trustworthy' (Al-Ameen) before prophethood?
questions.explanation: Even before prophethood, the people of Makkah called him Al-Ameen.

questions.text: Which is the only month mentioned by name in the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: Ramadan is mentioned in Surah Al-Baqarah, verse 185.

questions.text: What is the reward for reciting one letter of the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: The Prophet (SAW) said: 'Whoever reads a letter from the Book of Allah will receive 10 rewards.'

questions.text: How many gates does Paradise (Jannah) have?
questions.explanation: There are eight gates, one of which is called Baab As-Salah (for those who prayed regularly).

questions.text: Which prophet built the Ka’bah with his son?
questions.explanation: Prophet Ibrahim and his son Ismail rebuilt the Ka’bah.

questions.text: What is the first month of the Islamic (Hijri) calendar?
questions.explanation: Muharram is the first month and one of the four sacred months.

questions.text: Which surah begins with 'By the fig and the olive'?
questions.explanation: Surah At-Teen (95) starts with oaths by the fig and olive.

questions.text: Who was the first martyr (shaheed) in Islam?
questions.explanation: Sumayyah (RA) was killed by Abu Jahl for accepting Islam.

questions.text: Which animal carried the Prophet (SAW) during Mi'raj?
questions.explanation: Buraq was a heavenly mount faster than lightning.

questions.text: How many times is the word 'Allah' mentioned in the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: The name 'Allah' appears 2698 times in the Qur’an.

questions.text: Which prophet is mentioned most frequently in the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: Prophet Musa (AS) is mentioned 136 times.

questions.text: What is the greatest verse (Ayat al-Kursi) found in which surah?
questions.explanation: Ayat al-Kursi is verse 255 of Surah Al-Baqarah.

questions.text: Which companion was known as 'The Lion of Allah' (Asadullah)?
questions.explanation: Hamza (RA) was given this title by the Prophet (SAW).

questions.text: Which treaty ended the state of war between Muslims and Quraysh?
questions.explanation: Signed in 6 AH, it was a 10-year peace treaty.

questions.text: Which surah is recited in every rak’ah of salah?
questions.explanation: Surah Al-Fatiha is obligatory in every rak’ah.

questions.text: What is the meaning of 'Zakat'?
questions.explanation: Zakat means both purification and growth.

questions.text: How many prophets are mentioned by name in the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: 25 prophets are explicitly named, including Adam, Nuh, Ibrahim, Musa, Isa, and Muhammad (peace be upon them all).

questions.text: Which city was the first capital of the Islamic state?
questions.explanation: Madinah became the capital after the Hijrah in 622 CE.

questions.text: What is the night of Laylat al-Qadr better than?
questions.explanation: Laylat al-Qadr is better than a thousand months (Qur’an 97:3).

questions.text: Which companion memorized the entire Qur’an during the Prophet’s lifetime?
questions.explanation: Many companions (Huffaz) memorized the full Qur’an while the Prophet was alive.

questions.text: What is the Arabic word for 'pilgrimage'?
questions.explanation: Hajj is the fifth pillar performed in Dhul-Hijjah.

questions.text: Which prophet spoke as a newborn baby?
questions.explanation: Prophet Isa (Jesus) spoke from the cradle to defend his mother Maryam.

questions.text: What is the meaning of 'SAW' we say after the Prophet’s name?
questions.explanation: Sallallahu Alayhi Wasallam means 'Peace and blessings be upon him'.

questions.text: Which surah has the same number of verses as the number of surahs in the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: Surah An-Nas is the 114th surah and has 6 verses (but the question refers to its position).

questions.text: What is the reward for performing Hajj Mabrur (accepted Hajj)?
questions.explanation: The Prophet (SAW) said: 'There is no reward for accepted Hajj except Paradise.'

questions.text: Which companion was known as 'The Interpreter of the Qur’an'?
questions.explanation: Ibn Abbas (RA) was a young cousin of the Prophet and a great scholar of Tafsir.

questions.text: What is the last verse revealed of the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: Surah Al-Ma’idah 5:3 was revealed during the Farewell Hajj: 'This day I have perfected your religion…'

questions.text: Which prophet was swallowed by a whale?
questions.explanation: Prophet Yunus (Jonah) spent days inside a whale before being saved.

questions.text: What is the meaning of 'As-Salamu Alaikum'?
questions.explanation: The Islamic greeting of peace.

questions.text: Which surah is called 'Umm al-Kitab' (Mother of the Book)?
questions.explanation: Al-Fatiha is also called As-Sab’a al-Mathani and Umm al-Qur’an.

questions.text: How many years did Prophet Nuh (AS) preach to his people?
questions.explanation: Qur’an (29:14) states he stayed among them 950 years.

questions.text: What is the reward for fasting on the Day of Arafah (for non-pilgrims)?

options.text: Forgiveness of past and future minor sins

questions.explanation: Forgiveness of the previous year and the coming year.

questions.text: Which surah mentions the story of the People of the Cave (Ashab al-Kahf)?
questions.explanation: Surah Al-Kahf tells the story of youths who slept for centuries.

questions.text: What is the first word revealed of the Qur’an?
questions.explanation: The first word revealed was 'Iqra' (Read/Recite) in Cave Hira.

questions.text: Which prophet is known as 'Father of the Prophets'?
questions.explanation: Prophet Ibrahim (AS) is called Abu al-Anbiya (Father of the Prophets).

categories.name: Legal and Ethical Framework for AI

questions.text: Which branch of philosophy systematically examines right and wrong to guide moral behavior?
questions.explanation: Ethics is the philosophical study of right and wrong, guiding individual and collective behavior.

questions.text: In the context of technology, morality is best described as:
questions.explanation: Morality encompasses societal norms, traditions, and cultural values that define acceptable behavior.

questions.text: Which of the following is a deontological concern in AI?

options.text: Privacy vs. public safety in surveillance
A software engineer's duty to report unsafe code

questions.explanation: Deontology refers to professional duties and rules, such as a programmer's responsibility to ensure safety.

questions.text: The PAPA model in ICT ethics was proposed by:
questions.explanation: Richard Mason introduced the PAPA model in 1986 to address ethical issues in ICT.

questions.text: Which component of the PAPA model is concerned with protecting intellectual property?
questions.explanation: Property in the PAPA model refers to intellectual property rights and protection.

questions.text: The term 'Artificial Intelligence' was coined at which conference?
questions.explanation: The Dartmouth Conference in 1956 is widely considered the birth of AI as a field.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Narrow AI?

options.text: A chatbot with general reasoning abilities
A system that can perform any intellectual task a human can
Siri or Alexa performing specific tasks

questions.explanation: Narrow AI is designed for specific tasks (e.g., voice assistants) and does not possess general intelligence.

questions.text: Which ethical principle requires AI decisions to be interpretable?
questions.explanation: Transparency involves making AI systems understandable and explainable to users.

questions.text: Which organization released the 'Montreal Declaration for Responsible AI'?
questions.explanation: The Montreal Declaration was developed by researchers at the University of Montreal in 2018.

questions.text: The EU AI Act classifies AI systems based on:
questions.explanation: The EU AI Act categorizes AI into unacceptable, high, limited, and minimal risk levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered an 'unacceptable risk' under the EU AI Act?
questions.explanation: Social scoring systems are banned under the EU AI Act due to their threat to fundamental rights.

questions.text: The Partnership on AI was founded in:
questions.explanation: The Partnership on AI was established in 2016 by major tech companies and civil society groups.

questions.text: Which ethical principle is violated if an AI hiring tool favors one gender over another?
questions.explanation: Fairness requires AI systems to avoid discrimination based on gender, race, or other protected characteristics.

questions.text: Which real-world example illustrates an ethical dilemma in AI surveillance?
questions.explanation: China's social credit system raises ethical questions about surveillance, privacy, and human dignity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a moral dilemma related to AI?

options.text: Bias in a recidivism prediction tool
Failure to report a software safety flaw

questions.explanation: Moral dilemmas involve societal values, such as the ethics of designing algorithms that exploit psychological vulnerabilities.

questions.text: The ACM Code of Ethics is an example of:
questions.explanation: The ACM Code of Ethics is a professional deontological code guiding the conduct of computing professionals.

questions.text: Which principle of the PAPA model addresses the digital divide?
questions.explanation: Accessibility focuses on equitable access to technology and bridging the digital divide.

questions.text: General AI is characterized by:

options.text: Human-like general intelligence across diverse tasks

questions.explanation: General AI refers to systems with human-like intelligence capable of performing any intellectual task.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key principle in Google's AI ethics charter?
questions.explanation: Google's AI principles include avoiding bias, ensuring safety, and promoting social benefit.

questions.text: The 2010 Flash Crash is an example of a failure in which PAPA component?
questions.explanation: The Flash Crash was caused by inaccurate algorithmic trading, highlighting the importance of data reliability.

questions.text: Which ethical principle is most closely related to data encryption in health apps?
questions.explanation: Security involves protecting data from breaches, often through encryption and compliance with standards like HIPAA.

questions.text: The OECD AI principles emphasize:

options.text: Robust, safe, fair, and trustworthy AI
Promoting AI only in wealthy nations

questions.explanation: The OECD promotes AI that is robust, safe, fair, and trustworthy, with principles updated in 2025.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of AI in healthcare?
questions.explanation: DeepMind's AlphaFold predicts protein structures, aiding drug discovery and healthcare research.

questions.text: The EU high-level expert group on AI was established in:
questions.explanation: The European Commission formed the high-level expert group in 2018 to guide trustworthy AI development.

questions.text: Which of the following is a deontological dilemma?

options.text: Whether to use facial recognition in public spaces
A programmer hiding a known safety flaw
The societal impact of automation on jobs

questions.explanation: Deontological dilemmas involve professional duties, such as the obligation to report safety issues.

questions.text: UNESCO's ethical recommendations for AI include:
questions.explanation: UNESCO promotes human-centered AI with principles like safety, responsibility, transparency, and fairness.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an ethical dilemma in AI?

options.text: Using copyrighted art in AI training

questions.explanation: Ethical dilemmas involve weighing competing values, such as public safety vs. privacy in surveillance systems.

questions.text: The 'right to explanation' in the EU refers to:

options.text: The right to access AI source code
The right to know why an AI made a decision
The right to refuse AI services
The right to own AI-generated content

questions.explanation: The 'right to explanation' is part of the GDPR and EU AI Act, requiring transparency in automated decisions.

questions.text: Which of the following initiatives aims to bridge the urban-rural digital divide?
questions.explanation: India's Digital India program aims to improve digital infrastructure and access in rural areas.

questions.text: Responsibility and accountability in AI governance refer to:

options.text: Ensuring AI is used only by governments

questions.explanation: Responsibility and accountability involve defining who is liable when AI systems cause harm or errors.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key concern in AI intellectual property?

options.text: Using copyrighted works in training data

questions.explanation: Intellectual property concerns in AI include using copyrighted material (e.g., art, text) without permission for training.

questions.text: The Equifax data hack is an example of a failure in which ethical area?
questions.explanation: The Equifax breach raised ethical questions about corporate responsibility in protecting user data.

questions.text: Which AI application raises significant privacy concerns?
questions.explanation: Amazon Rekognition, a facial and voice recognition system, raises concerns about surveillance and privacy.

questions.text: The COMPAS recidivism tool is an example of:

options.text: A transparent and fair AI system
An AI system with no ethical issues

questions.explanation: COMPAS has been criticized for racial bias, illustrating fairness and discrimination challenges in AI.

questions.text: Which principle is part of Microsoft's AI ethics charter?

options.text: Maximizing user engagement at all costs

questions.explanation: Microsoft's AI principles include fairness, reliability, privacy, inclusivity, transparency, and accountability.

questions.text: Which of the following is a focus of the Montreal Declaration?
questions.explanation: The Montreal Declaration outlines principles like well-being, autonomy, justice, and solidarity for responsible AI.

questions.text: Which organization updated its AI principles in 2025?
questions.explanation: Both OECD and UNESCO updated their AI guidelines and toolkits in 2025.

questions.text: AI in agriculture includes:
questions.explanation: AI in agriculture uses drones and sensors for precision farming, soil health analysis, and crop monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following is a high-risk application under the EU AI Act?
questions.explanation: Biometric identification is classified as high-risk due to its impact on fundamental rights.

questions.text: The Boeing 737 MAX software flaw is an example of:
questions.explanation: The Boeing case highlights a failure in professional duty and safety standards, a deontological issue.

questions.text: Which AI ethical principle is most related to preventing algorithmic bias?
questions.explanation: Fairness involves ensuring AI does not discriminate and treats all groups equitably.

questions.text: Stable Diffusion's use of artists' works without permission raises issues of:
questions.explanation: Using copyrighted art in AI training data breaches intellectual property rights.

questions.text: Which of the following is a goal of the Partnership on AI?

options.text: To accelerate AI development without oversight
To develop frameworks for safe and beneficial AI
To promote AI only in the private sector

questions.explanation: The Partnership on AI works on best practices, guidelines, and frameworks for responsible AI.

questions.text: TikTok's addictive algorithms are primarily a:
questions.explanation: Addictive algorithms raise moral questions about exploiting psychological vulnerabilities for profit.

questions.text: Which AI application is used in finance?
questions.explanation: Algorithmic trading firms like Renaissance Technologies use AI to optimize financial investments.

questions.text: The GDPR is primarily concerned with:
questions.explanation: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) focuses on data privacy, security, and user rights.

questions.text: Which of the following is a principle of trustworthy AI according to the EU?
questions.explanation: The EU's framework for trustworthy AI emphasizes human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, and justice.

questions.text: Predictive maintenance in manufacturing is an example of:
questions.explanation: Predictive maintenance uses AI for a specific task (reducing downtime), characteristic of Narrow AI.

questions.text: Which of the following universities is mentioned for advancing AI ethics research?
questions.explanation: Stanford and Cambridge are highlighted for their research centers and contributions to applied AI ethics.

questions.text: The main purpose of ethical frameworks in AI is to:

options.text: Ensure AI benefits society while minimizing harm

questions.explanation: Ethical frameworks guide the responsible development and use of AI to promote societal good and prevent harm.

questions.text: What is the primary definition of a social network?

options.text: A business tool for marketing and advertising
A digital platform for creating profiles, sharing content, and interacting

questions.explanation: A social network is defined as a digital platform enabling users to create profiles, generate and share content, and interact through features like posting and messaging.

questions.text: Which platform is specifically tailored for professional networking and career development?
questions.explanation: LinkedIn is designed for professional networking, job postings, and career development.

questions.text: Which type of responsibility involves liabilities for damages to third parties through disseminated content?
questions.explanation: Civil responsibility pertains to liabilities for damages inflicted on third parties through content on the platform.

questions.text: Which U.S. law provides immunity from civil liability for user-generated content, but has seen narrowed protection in 2025?

options.text: Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act

questions.explanation: Section 230 grants immunity, but recent court interpretations in 2025 have reduced protection in cases involving algorithmic amplification of harmful posts.

questions.text: Which responsibility regime involves obligations from Terms of Service (ToS) or user agreements?
questions.explanation: Contractual responsibility is based on the platform's commitments in its Terms of Service or user agreements.

questions.text: In which jurisdiction are crimes committed via social media treated as local offenses?
questions.explanation: In the UAE, social media crimes are prosecuted as local offenses, holding platforms accountable.

questions.text: What is a key social issue related to social network management mentioned for 2025?
questions.explanation: A highlighted social issue for 2025 is increased harassment enabled by anonymous interactions on platforms.

questions.text: Which economic issue is driven by targeted advertising and data monetization?
questions.explanation: Targeted advertising relies on user profiling, raising significant privacy and ethical concerns.

questions.text: What technological risk is heightened by AI integration in social networks by 2025?

options.text: Data security breaches and privacy violations

questions.explanation: Advanced AI integration increases risks related to data security, privacy breaches, and ethical misuse.

questions.text: Which European regulation mandates stringent personal data protection for social networks?
questions.explanation: The GDPR is the key EU regulation enforcing strict rules on personal data protection and privacy.

questions.text: Which act, fully enforced by 2025, imposes content moderation and minor protection obligations on platforms in the EU?
questions.explanation: The Digital Services Act (DSA), fully enforced by 2025, sets strict rules for content moderation and protecting minors online.

questions.text: What is a best practice for social networks to ensure accountability and transparency?
questions.explanation: Algorithm audits help identify and mitigate bias, promoting transparency and fairness in content recommendation systems.

questions.text: Which 2025 example involved the spread of fake news via bots on platforms like X?
questions.explanation: In 2024-2025, Russian disinformation networks used AI-enhanced bots to spread fake news on platforms like X (Twitter).

questions.text: What is a major challenge in algorithmic moderation of sensitive content?
questions.explanation: Algorithms often struggle to understand context and intent, leading to inconsistent removal of hate speech or deepfakes.

questions.text: Which U.S. law is designed to protect the privacy of children under 13 online?
questions.explanation: COPPA (Children's Online Privacy Protection Act) sets requirements for websites and online services directed at children under 13.

questions.text: What ethical issue arises from the use of algorithms in social networks?

options.text: Lack of transparency and potential bias

questions.explanation: A core ethical issue is the lack of transparency in how algorithms work and their potential to amplify bias and misinformation.

questions.text: Which responsibility goes beyond legal mandates to include protecting user data and combating disinformation?
questions.explanation: Ethical and social responsibility involves voluntary actions to protect users and society, beyond what is legally required.

questions.text: What is projected to be a major economic trend in the U.S. creator economy by 2025?
questions.explanation: By 2025, brands are projected to spend approximately $37 billion on creator economy advertising in the U.S.

questions.text: Which practical case highlighted ethical lapses in the collection and use of personal data?
questions.explanation: Cases involving generative AI misusing collected user data underscore significant ethical failures in data handling and monetization.

questions.text: How do algorithms contribute to the spread of misinformation according to 2025 reviews?

options.text: By blocking all false content automatically
By amplifying it through cognitive biases and platform mechanics
By charging users for verified information
By reducing the speed of content sharing

questions.explanation: Algorithms are designed to maximize engagement, which often inadvertently promotes misinformation by leveraging human cognitive biases and platform features.

questions.text: What does IoT stand for and what is its core function?

options.text: Internet of Technology – To replace human jobs
Internet of Things – To connect devices that collect and exchange data without human input
Integrated Online Technology – To enhance cybersecurity
Intelligent Operating Terminals – To process data locally

questions.explanation: IoT stands for Internet of Things, a network of interconnected devices that communicate and process data autonomously.

questions.text: Which of the following is a major ethical challenge posed by IoT?

options.text: Massive collection of sensitive data and privacy risks

questions.explanation: IoT devices collect vast amounts of personal data, raising significant privacy and surveillance concerns.

questions.text: What does the ethical principle of 'transparency' require in IoT systems?

options.text: Users must understand how their data is processed and used
All software code must be open-source

questions.explanation: Transparency means users should be clearly informed about data flows, algorithms, and system functioning.

questions.text: Which legal framework is most directly relevant to data protection in IoT devices in the EU?
questions.explanation: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) sets strict rules for data privacy and protection in the EU, applicable to IoT.

questions.text: What is a key cybersecurity principle mentioned for IoT in 2025?
questions.explanation: Zero Trust security models, which assume no implicit trust, are emphasized for IoT systems to prevent unauthorized access.

questions.text: In the context of IoT, what does 'data minimization' refer to?

options.text: Collecting only the data necessary for a specific purpose

questions.explanation: Data minimization is a privacy principle that involves collecting only the data that is directly relevant and necessary.

questions.text: What is the primary ethical dilemma in the 'trolley problem' as applied to autonomous vehicles?

options.text: Whether to use electric or gasoline power
Choosing between utilitarian (save most lives) vs. deontological (follow rules) outcomes in unavoidable accidents
Deciding which brand of sensor to use

questions.explanation: The trolley problem highlights the moral conflict between saving the greatest number (utilitarianism) and adhering to moral rules like 'do not kill' (deontology).

questions.text: Which SAE level of autonomy describes a car that can drive itself under specific conditions but may require human intervention?
questions.explanation: SAE Level 3 is 'conditional automation' – the vehicle drives itself in certain environments but expects the human to take over when needed.

questions.text: Who is most likely to be held liable if a Level 5 autonomous vehicle causes an accident due to a software failure?

options.text: The city where the accident occurred

questions.explanation: In high-autonomy vehicles (Level 4/5), liability often shifts to manufacturers under product liability laws, especially if a system failure is the cause.

questions.text: What does V2X connectivity in autonomous vehicles enable?

options.text: Communication with infrastructure, other vehicles, and pedestrians

questions.explanation: V2X (Vehicle-to-Everything) allows AVs to communicate with traffic lights, other cars, and even pedestrians' devices for safer coordination.

questions.text: Which of the following is a social impact concern regarding widespread AV adoption?
questions.explanation: Autonomous vehicles could displace jobs for drivers (truck, taxi, delivery), raising ethical concerns about economic inequality.

questions.text: What is the purpose of an ethical charter like the Montreal Declaration for Responsible AI in the context of AVs?

options.text: To set maximum speed limits for AVs
To promote principles like well-being, autonomy, and equity in AI development
To standardize battery sizes for electric AVs

questions.explanation: Ethical charters provide guiding principles to ensure AI (and AV) development aligns with human values such as fairness, safety, and transparency.

questions.text: Which regulatory body in the US provides oversight and reports on autonomous vehicle safety?
questions.explanation: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) oversees vehicle safety in the US, including AVs.

questions.text: What does 'bias in embedded algorithms' in IoT refer to?

options.text: Preference for certain brands of hardware
Systematic errors in AI that favor or disadvantage certain groups of people
Slow processing speed in older devices

questions.explanation: Algorithmic bias occurs when AI systems produce unfairly skewed results due to prejudiced training data or flawed design, leading to discrimination.

questions.text: In ethical IoT design, what does 'equity and access' primarily address?

options.text: Ensuring technology is affordable and available to underserved populations
Using equal amounts of data for all users

questions.explanation: Equity in IoT focuses on bridging the digital divide so that benefits of technology are accessible to all, regardless of socioeconomic status.

questions.text: Which 2025 EU regulation specifically integrates governance for autonomous vehicles?
questions.explanation: The EU's AI Act (effective around 2025) sets harmonized rules for AI systems, including those used in autonomous vehicles.

questions.text: What is a 'robotaxi pilot' as mentioned in the chapter?

options.text: A real-world test of autonomous ride-hailing services
A video game about futuristic taxis
A pilot program for human taxi drivers

questions.explanation: A robotaxi pilot is a controlled, real-world deployment of autonomous vehicles for public ride-hailing, like Nissan's 2025 test in Japan.

questions.text: How do international standards like ISO contribute to AV safety?

options.text: By providing universal cybersecurity and functional safety frameworks
By requiring all AVs to be electric

questions.explanation: ISO standards (e.g., ISO 21434 for cybersecurity) provide internationally recognized guidelines to ensure AVs are safe and secure by design.

questions.text: What is the 'digital divide' in the context of IoT ethics?

options.text: A gap in digital screen quality
The inequality in access to technology and the internet between different groups
A divide between software and hardware engineers

questions.explanation: The digital divide refers to the gap between those who have access to modern information technology and those who do not, often due to economic or geographic factors.

questions.text: Why is anonymity important in smart city IoT applications?

options.text: To protect individual privacy when collecting pedestrian or traffic data

questions.explanation: Anonymizing data (removing personally identifiable information) is a key privacy measure to prevent surveillance and misuse in public IoT systems.

questions.text: What is the core definition of the Digital Revolution?

options.text: The invention of the personal computer.
The profound societal upheaval driven by widespread adoption of digital technologies.
The shift from coal to electricity in industry.
The creation of the World Wide Web.

questions.explanation: The Digital Revolution is broadly defined as the deep transformation of societies due to the mass integration of digital tools, moving from analog to digital systems.

questions.text: Which characteristic of the Digital Revolution refers to the conversion of analog information into binary formats?
questions.explanation: Digitization is the fundamental process of converting analog signals (text, sound, image) into digital data (bits and bytes) for storage and processing.

questions.text: The massive increase in data volume generated and analyzed is best termed as:
questions.explanation: 'Big Data' refers to the exponential growth in the volume, velocity, and variety of data, a key characteristic of the digital age.

questions.text: Which period is associated with the democratization of computing through the introduction of personal computers (PCs)?
questions.explanation: The 1980s saw the rise of personal computers like the IBM PC and Apple Macintosh, making computing accessible to the general public.

questions.text: The development of the World Wide Web, revolutionizing global communication, is a key milestone of which decade?
questions.explanation: While invented in 1989, the World Wide Web became a widespread public phenomenon in the 1990s with the first web browsers and portals.

questions.text: Which Industrial Revolution first introduced computing and automation as pivotal elements?
questions.explanation: The Third Industrial Revolution (mid-20th century) is defined by the rise of computers, electronics, and early automation, with the Internet as a key development.

questions.text: Industry 4.0, or the current Digital Revolution, is characterized by the fusion of:

options.text: Digital technologies, AI, and the Internet of Things (IoT).

questions.explanation: The Fourth Industrial Revolution (Industry 4.0) merges digital, biological, and physical systems, heavily relying on AI, IoT, and smart, connected factories.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a social challenge posed by the Digital Revolution?

options.text: High energy consumption of data centers

questions.explanation: The digital divide is a major social challenge, referring to inequalities in access to technology and the internet, which can lead to social and educational exclusion.

questions.text: What is a primary environmental challenge associated with the digital infrastructure?

options.text: Creation of new professions like data scientists
The spread of disinformation on social media
Significant energy consumption by data centers

questions.explanation: Data centers that power cloud computing, streaming, and online services consume vast amounts of electricity, contributing to the digital carbon footprint.

questions.text: The 2018 Facebook-Cambridge Analytica scandal is a prime example of which ethical challenge?
questions.explanation: The scandal involved the unauthorized harvesting and use of personal data from millions of Facebook users, highlighting massive privacy risks.

questions.text: When an AI recruiting tool favors male candidates because it was trained on historical data from a male-dominated industry, this demonstrates:
questions.explanation: Algorithmic bias occurs when AI systems perpetuate or amplify existing societal prejudices due to biased training data or flawed model design.

questions.text: Which application domain of the Digital Revolution is exemplified by the use of 'digital twins' in manufacturing?
questions.explanation: Digital twins are virtual replicas of physical assets or processes used in Industry 4.0 to simulate, analyze, and optimize manufacturing operations in real-time.

questions.text: The principle that AI systems should be designed to augment human decision-making rather than replace human agency entirely speaks to which ethical concern?
questions.explanation: Preserving 'The Human Role' is a key ethical challenge, ensuring that humans remain in control, accountable, and that technology enhances rather than diminishes human capabilities.

questions.text: Why is ethical reflection considered essential in the context of AI and the Digital Revolution?

options.text: Because it slows down technological progress to a safer pace.
Because AI's central role amplifies both benefits and risks, impacting human rights and social stability.
Because ethics is a legal requirement for all software development.
Because it is primarily a public relations concern for tech companies.

questions.explanation: AI is a transformative force at the core of the digital revolution. Without ethical guidelines, its power can lead to significant harm, making proactive ethical reflection crucial.

questions.text: Tools like the EU's AI Act and UNESCO's ethical recommendations are examples of what?
questions.explanation: These are frameworks designed to create boundaries and principles (both legal and ethical) to govern the development and use of AI, balancing innovation with public protection.

questions.text: Which of the following is an economic challenge specifically related to automation?

options.text: The need for workforce retraining and reskilling.
Collection of personal data by corporations.

questions.explanation: While automation boosts productivity, it disrupts the labor market by displacing certain jobs, creating a critical need for retraining programs to transition workers into new roles.

questions.text: What does 'interconnectivity' in the Digital Revolution primarily refer to?

options.text: Networks like the IoT enabling devices and systems to communicate.
Converting paper records to digital files.
Using data to train AI algorithms.

questions.explanation: Interconnectivity is the networking of devices, machines, and people through the Internet and the Internet of Things (IoT), creating a seamlessly connected ecosystem.

questions.text: Precision farming in agriculture, which uses sensors and data analytics, is an application of the Digital Revolution that primarily leverages:

options.text: A combination of digitization, data, and interconnectivity.

questions.explanation: Precision farming integrates multiple digital characteristics: digitization (converting soil/weather data), data explosion (analyzing vast datasets), and interconnectivity (IoT sensors in fields).

questions.text: The question of liability in an accident involving an autonomous vehicle highlights which key ethical challenge?
questions.explanation: This challenge involves determining accountability (responsibility) for decisions made by AI systems and requires clarity (transparency) in how those decisions are reached.

questions.text: Which historical stage in digital evolution was marked by the invention of the microprocessor, making computers smaller and more affordable?
questions.explanation: The invention of the microprocessor, like Intel's 4004 in 1971, was the key technological breakthrough that enabled the creation of smaller, cheaper, and more powerful computers.
